Filters.filterDesc: A class in programming languages serves as a blueprint or template for creating objects, which are instances of that class.
A function in programming languages is a self-contained block of code that performs a specific task that are executed when it is called.
A variable in programming languages is a named storage location used to hold data that can change during the execution of a program.
An if-Else conditional in programming languages is a control flow statement based on whether a condition is true or false.
A switch-case conditional in programming languages is a control flow statement based on the value of a variable.
A loop in programming languages is a control flow statement that allows to execute a block of code multiple times.
A while loop in programming languages is a control flow statement that allows to execute a code block while checking a condition.

Playgrounds.playgroundDesc: A Class is a fundamental concept in object-oriented programming (OOP). It serves as a blueprint or template for creating objects. A class encapsulates data for the object (attributes or properties) and functions (methods) that operate on the data.
A function is a self-contained block of code that performs a specific task.
A variable is a named storage location used to hold data that can change during the execution of a program.
An if-else conditional in programming languages is a control flow statement that allows you to execute different code blocks based on whether a condition is true or false.
A switch-case conditional in programming languages is a control flow statement that allows a variable to be tested against a list of values, each with an associated block of code to execute.
A for loop in programming languages is a control flow statement used to repeatedly execute a block of code a certain number of times or over a sequence of values.
A while loop in programming languages is is a control flow statement that allows code to be executed repeatedly based on a given Boolean condition
